title: SKIN CARE: Corona company ships products around the world
text:
BY FIELDING BUCK / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 1, 2015 Updated: Oct. 2, 2015 9:06 p.m. SKIN CARE: Corona company ships products around the world 1 of 3 More Related article » MORE ON TRIDERMA Founded: 1992 in Anaheim
Moved to Corona: 2014
Information: triderma.com/
Gloria Vanderlaan initially didn’t set her sights on Target when she founded TriDerma a quarter century ago.
Yet a few years after she launched a line of specialty skin creams and moisturizers, they made it onto the shelves of Target, Kmart, Wal-Mart, Walgreens and other majors in the retail world.
“It was more difficult to stay in than to get in at that time,” she said in a recent phone interview. “Now it’s more difficult to get in.”
TriDerma aims to provide relief to people with medical conditions, such as people who have raw skin after cosmetic surgery.
Vanderlaan was seeking relief from a dermabrasion that left her skin raw and wounded when she founded TriDerma in 1992. The company moved to Corona last year.
“It got rid of wrinkles, but it got rid of every thing else, too,” she said. “If you’ve ever had a scab from falling off a bicycle or motorcycle, that’s the kind of scab that was created.
“I set out to figure out what we could formulate for other women.”
The advice she got was to use Crisco, the shortening used for baking and frying chicken, because it was “really thick” and there were no skin products available to seal her skin.
“They needed an occlusive, something to put on the skin to keep it from drying out and to keep it covered, basically. So we set out originally to formulate an occlusive that could be used after plastic surgery procedures. And to this day we still sell in that market.”
The company now has almost 50 products sold in various sizes in the United States and internationally. It has products for post-surgical care, diabetic care, baby care, first aid, acne and other specialized needs. Most sell for $6.99 to $24.99 on the TriDerma website.
From August through October, TriDerma is donating 20 percent of its proceeds from certain products to the American Childhood Cancer Organization. They are products that could be useful for sick children: foot cream, bruise relief, radiation relief, post-laser occlusive and scar-healing gel.
In addition to retail, TriDerma’s markets include hospital supply companies, home health care and independent pharmacies. And Vanderlaan would like to expand into pet care products.
TriDerma got into the majors because it had a niche, a Goldilocks-like sweet spot between medicine and competitors’ creams that had little effect.
“We were kind of in the middle. We weren’t a drug, so we didn’t have the side effects. But we were more efficacious than the average product that sat on the shelf.”
Even though TriDerma products aren’t defined as drugs, Vanderlaan says they have integrity.
